subject: Ethics
title: The Panopticon Effect
description: A fast breakdown of The Panopticon Effect for builders.

hook.text: In 1791, Jeremy Bentham designed a prison where one guard could watch every inmate â€” but inmates couldn't tell.

buildup.text: He called it the Panopticon. The trick? Prisoners behaved as if watched all the time, even when nobody looked.

discovery.text: Foucault saw this as a metaphor: when you might be watched, you police yourself. No guard needed.

twist.text: Tech built a digital Panopticon. Your webcam, mic, and location tracker are always potentially on.

climax.text: The chilling effect is real: people self-censor online searches after learning about surveillance.

punchline.text: You don't need a guard if the camera light is on.

quiz.question: What is the 'Panopticon effect' on behavior?
options: People behave differently when they think they might be watched
Only prisoners are affected by surveillance
